    });

Simply rename the file:</p><ul><li><p><b>From:</b> <code>lib/blogs.js</code></p></li><li><p><b>To:</b> <code>lib/blog.js</code></p></li></ul><hr><p></p><h3>3. <b>Critical:</b> Rename <code>components/layout.js</code> to <code>components/Layout.js</code></h3><p></p><p>Similar to the issue above, there's a case-sensitivity mismatch. Deployment platforms like Cloudflare use Linux, where filenames are case-sensitive.</p><ul><li><p>Your file is named: <code>components/layout.js</code> (lowercase "l").</p></li><li><p>Your pages are importing it as <code>../components/Layout</code> (uppercase "L").</p></li></ul><p><b>How to Fix It:</b>
Rename the file to match the import statement:</p><ul><li><p><b>From:</b> <code>components/layout.js</code></p></li><li><p><b>To:</b> <code>components/Layout.js</code></p></li></ul><hr><p></p><h3>4. <b>Important:</b> Configure Your CMS and Git Repo</h3><p></p><p>Your <code>config.yml</code> file still has the placeholder repository name. The CMS will not be able to connect to your GitHub account until you fix this.</p><p><b>The Issue:</b>
In <code>public/admin/config.yml</code>, the <code>repo</code> field is still <code>your-github-username/your-repo-name</code>.</p><p><b>How to Fix It:</b>
Update this line with your actual GitHub username and the name of the repository you created.</p><p><b>Example:</b></p><response-element class="" Let's break down that code snippet and explain exactly what <code>YOUR_UNIQUE_ID</code> is and how you get it.</p><p></p><h3>What is this Code Doing?</h3><p></p><p>This <code>handleSubmit</code> function is the engine for your contact form. Its job is to take the data the user typed in (name, email, message) and send it somewhere so you can receive it as an email.</p><p>Since your website is a static site (built with Next.js and hosted on Cloudflare), it doesn't have a backend server to process this email directly. That's where <b>Formspree</b> comes in.</p><p><b>Formspree</b> is a free service that acts as the "backend" for your form. You send your form data to their special URL, and they handle the complicated task of turning that data into an email and sending it to you.</p><p></p><h3>What is <code>'https://formspree.io/f/YOUR_UNIQUE_ID'</code>?</h3><p></p><p>This is the special URL provided by Formspree. It's the endpoint where your form's data needs to be sent.</p><ul><li><p><code>https://formspree.io/f/</code> is the standard base URL for all Formspree forms.</p></li><li><p><code>YOUR_UNIQUE_ID</code> is a <b>placeholder</b>. You need to replace it with the actual, unique 8-character ID that Formspree gives you when you create a form with them. Each form you create will have its own unique ID.</p></li></ul><p></p><h3>How to Get Your Unique ID from Formspree</h3><p></p><p>Follow these simple steps:</p><ol start="1"><li><p><b>Sign Up for Formspree</b>: Go to <response-element class="" ng-version="0.0.0-PLACEHOLDER"><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><link-block _nghost-ng-c2663339354="" class="ng-star-inserted"><!----><!----><!----><a _ngcontent-ng-c2663339354="" target="_blank" rel="noopener" externallink="" _nghost-ng-c975547607="" jslog="197247;track:generic_click,impression,attention;BardVeMetadataKey:[[&quot;r_83b8ec672129e843&quot;,&quot;c_f077fe428a5a0c48&quot;,null,&quot;rc_1de74c1a49e7b5d3&quot;,null,null,&quot;en&quot;,null,1,null,null,1,1]]" href="https://formspree.io/" class="ng-star-inserted" data-hveid="4">formspree.io</a><!----></link-block><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----></response-element> and create a free account.</p></li><li><p><b>Create a New Form</b>:</p><ul><li><p>In your Formspree dashboard, click the <b>"+ New form"</b> button.</p></li><li><p>Give your form a name (e.g., "My Blog Contact Form").</p></li><li><p>Enter the email address where you want to receive messages from your contact form.</p></li><li><p>Click <b>"Create Form"</b>.</p></li></ul></li><li><p><b>Copy Your Unique Endpoint URL</b>:</p><ul><li><p>Formspree will now show you your unique endpoint URL. It will look something like this:
<code>https://formspree.io/f/xbjvwqea</code></p></li><li><p>The 8-character string at the end (<code>xbjvwqea</code> in this example) is <b>your unique ID</b>.</p></li></ul></li><li><p><b>Update Your Code</b>:</p><ul><li><p>Copy the entire URL.</p></li><li><p>Go back to your <code>pages/contact.js</code> file and replace the placeholder with your actual URL.</p></li></ul></li></ol><p><b>Example:</b></p><response-element class="" ng-version="0.0.0-PLACEHOLDER"><!----><!----><!----><!----><code-block _nghost-ng-c3890993025="" stronger enable-updated-hr-color" id="model-response-message-contentr_6b16702017a8085e" dir="ltr" style="--animation-duration: 600ms; --fade-animation-function: linear;"><p>Based on the code in your <code>contact.js</code> file, here is an explanation of what Formspree is and why you need it for your project.</p><p></p><h3>What is Formspree?</h3><p></p><p>Formspree is an online service that acts as a simple backend for your website's forms. When a user fills out a form on your site (like your contact form), the data is sent to a unique Formspree URL. Formspree then processes this data and forwards it to your email address. It essentially handles the complicated task of receiving form submissions and turning them into emails for you.</p><p></p><h3>Why You Need It</h3><p></p><p>You need a service like Formspree because your website is a <b>static site</b>. Here's what that means for your contact form:</p><ol start="1"><li><p><b>No Backend Server</b>: Static sites are made of pre-built HTML, CSS, and JavaScript files that are sent directly to the user's browser. They don't have a traditional, constantly running backend server that can process data or send emails on its own.</p></li><li><p><b>The Contact Form's Problem</b>: Your contact form, located in <code>pages/contact.js</code>, collects the user's name, email, and message. However, without a backend, your website has no built-in way to take that information and send it to you as an email.</p></li><li><p><b>Formspree as the Solution</b>: Your code is set up to solve this problem by sending the form data to a Formspree URL. Formspree acts as the "middleman" or backend service, receiving the data and forwarding it to your email inbox.</p></li></ol><p>In short, you need Formspree to make your contact form functional on a static website without the complexity of setting up and maintaining your own email server.</p></div><!----></message-content><!----><!----><div _ngcontent-ng-c3182825971="" class="response-footer stronger enable-updated-hr-color" id="model-response-message-contentr_ff98e052b7a54a65" dir="ltr" style="--animation-duration: 600ms; --fade-animation-function: linear;"><p>You are absolutely right to question that! Thank you for bringing up the specific Cloudflare recommendation. My previous answer was based on the standard Next.js setup, but Cloudflare has since introduced a better, more optimized way to handle Next.js projects.</p><p>You should <b>follow the Cloudflare recommendation</b>. It is the most current and correct method.</p><p>Here is the breakdown of what to use and why:</p><p></p><h3><b>Build command</b></h3><p></p><ul><li><p><b>Use this command:</b> <code>npx @cloudflare/next-on-pages@1</code></p></li></ul><p><b>Why?</b>
<code>@cloudflare/next-on-pages</code> is a special build tool created by Cloudflare specifically for deploying Next.js sites on their platform. It takes the standard output from <code>next build</code> and intelligently adapts it to work perfectly with Cloudflare's infrastructure (like Pages and Workers). This ensures better performance and compatibility than the default build command alone.</p><p></p><h3><b>Build output directory</b></h3><p></p><ul><li><p><b>Use this directory:</b> <code>.vercel/output/static</code></p></li></ul><p><b>Why?</b>
When the <code>npx @cloudflare/next-on-pages@1</code> command runs, it generates an output folder that is optimized for Cloudflare Pages. This folder is named <code>.vercel/output/static</code>. This is the directory Cloudflare needs to find all your site's files to deploy them correctly.</p><p></p><h3>Summary of Final Settings</h3><p></p><p>So, in your Cloudflare Pages setup, you should configure the following:</p><ul><li><p><b>Framework preset</b>: <b>Next.js</b></p></li><li><p><b>Build command</b>: <code>npx @cloudflare/next-on-pages@1</code></p></li><li><p><b>Build output directory</b>: <code>.vercel/output/static</code></p></li></ul><p>You are correct to use these newer, recommended settings. the build log tells us exactly what's wrong. Let's get it fixed.</p><p></p><h3>The Problem</h3><p></p><p>The build is failing because the Cloudflare build process cannot find your <code>package.json</code> file.</p><p>The error message in your log clearly states:
<code>Error: No Next.js version detected. Make sure your package.json has "next" in either "dependencies" or "devDependencies". Also check your Root Directory setting matches the directory of your package.json file.</code></p><p>This happens when the <code>package.json</code> file is not in the main (root) folder of your project. I can see from your uploaded file list that your <code>package.json</code> file is accidentally located inside a <code>stlyes</code> folder.</p><p></p><h3>How to Fix It</h3><p></p><p>You need to move the <code>package.json</code> file to the top-level (root) of your <code>rohithegde_newsite</code> project folder.</p><p><b>1. Move the File:</b>
On your local computer, move the <code>package.json</code> file from:
<code>rohithegde_newsite/stlyes/package.json</code>
<b>to</b>
<code>rohithegde_newsite/package.json</code></p><p><b>2. Commit and Push the Change:</b>
Open your terminal, navigate to your project folder, and run these Git commands to update your repository:</p><response-element class="" <code>HEAD is now at cfa73c8 Update contact.js</code></p><p>This indicates that the latest commit Cloudflare is seeing is the one where you updated the contact page, not the newer commit where you moved the <code>package.json</code> file. This means the fix was likely not pushed to your GitHub repository correctly.</p><p></p><h3>How to Fix It</h3><p></p><p>You need to ensure your local changes are pushed to GitHub before you try to deploy on Cloudflare again.</p><p><b>1. Verify the File Location Locally:</b>
First, double-check on your own computer that <code>package.json</code> is now in the root of your <code>rohithegde_newsite</code> folder and <b>not</b> inside the <code>stlyes</code> folder.</p><p><b>2. Commit and Push the Fix:</b>
If the file is in the correct place locally, run these Git commands in your terminal from the project folder:</p><response-element class="" Here‚Äôs what the error means and how to fix it.</p><p></p><h3>What the Error Means</h3><p></p><p>The error message <code>Updates were rejected because the remote contains work that you do not have locally</code> means that your GitHub repository has changes or commits that your local machine is not aware of.</p><p>This usually happens if you (or someone else) made a change directly on the GitHub website, or from another computer. Git is preventing you from pushing your changes to avoid accidentally overwriting the new changes on the remote repository.</p><p></p><h3>How to Fix It</h3><p></p><p>As the hint in the error message suggests, you need to first download (pull) the remote changes and merge them with your local work before you can push again.</p><p>Here are the commands to run in your terminal:</p><p><b>1. Pull the Remote Changes:</b>
This command will fetch the latest version from GitHub and merge it into your local repository.</p><response-element class="" ng-version="0.0.0-PLACEHOLDER"><!----><!----><!----><!----><code-block Don't worry, this is normal and easy to fix.</p><p></p><h3>What Happened?</h3><p></p><p>The log shows <code>Automatic merge failed; fix conflicts and then commit the result.</code></p><p>This means:</p><ol start="1"><li><p>You have changes on your local computer (like adding the new Tailwind files).</p></li><li><p>The GitHub repository <i>also</i> has some changes that your computer didn't know about.</p></li><li><p>Git tried to combine them automatically but couldn't decide which changes to keep, so it's asking you to make the final decision.</p></li></ol><p>The conflicts are in <code>lib/blog.js</code> and with the new style files because the remote repository doesn't know you deleted the <code>stlyes</code> folder.</p><p></p><h3>How to Fix It (The Easy Way)</h3><p></p><p>The goal is to tell Git to accept <b>your local changes</b>, because we know they are the correct ones. Here is the safest and simplest way to do that.</p><p><b>Step 1: Abort the Merge</b>
First, let's undo the failed merge attempt to get back to a clean state. This will make your GitHub repository look exactly like your local folder.</p><p><b>1. Remove all previously tracked files from Git:</b>
This command tells Git to untrack everything, effectively deleting all files from the repository's history in the next commit. This is a file path issue.</p><p>Looking at the logs, we can see these specific errors:</p><ul><li><p><code>Module not found: Can't resolve '../styles/globals.css'</code></p></li><li><p><code>Module not found: Can't resolve '../../components/Layout'</code></p></li></ul><p>This means the build process is looking for the <code>styles</code> and <code>components</code> folders but cannot find them where it expects them to be. This usually happens because of a typo in a folder name or because the folders are in the wrong location.</p><p></p><h3>How to Fix It</h3><p></p><p>You need to ensure your project has the correct folder structure at the top level. All the main folders (<code>pages</code>, <code>components</code>, <code>styles</code>, <code>lib</code>, <code>public</code>, <code>_posts</code>) should be at the same root level as your <code>package.json</code> file.</p><p><b>1. <span class="hljs-keyword">import</span> fs <span class="hljs-keyword">from</span> <span class="hljs-string">'fs'</span>;
<span class="hljs-keyword">import</span> path <span class="hljs-keyword">from</span> <span class="hljs-string">'path'</span>;
<span class="hljs-keyword">import</span> matter <span class="hljs-keyword">from</span> <span class="hljs-string">'gray-matter'</span>;
<span class="hljs-keyword">import</span> { format } <span class="hljs-keyword">from</span> <span class="hljs-string">'date-fns'</span>;

<span class="hljs-comment">// Point to the directory where your markdown posts are stored</span>
<span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> postsDirectory = path.join(process.cwd(), <span class="hljs-string">'_posts'</span>);

<span class="hljs-comment">// Gets all posts and sorts them by date</span>
<span class="hljs-keyword">export</span> <span class="hljs-function"><span class="hljs-keyword">function</span> <span class="hljs-title">getAllPosts</span>(<span class="hljs-params"></span>) </span>{
  <span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> fileNames = fs.readdirSync(postsDirectory);
  <span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> allPostsData = fileNames.map(<span class="hljs-function">(<span class="hljs-params">fileName</span>) =&gt;</span> {
    <span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> slug = fileName.replace(<span class="hljs-regexp">/\.md$/</span>, <span class="hljs-string">''</span>);
    <span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> fullPath = path.join(postsDirectory, fileName);
    <span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> fileContents = fs.readFileSync(fullPath, <span class="hljs-string">'utf8'</span>);
    <span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> matterResult = matter(fileContents);
    <span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> formattedDate = format(<span class="hljs-keyword">new</span> <span class="hljs-built_in">Date</span>(matterResult.data.date), <span class="hljs-string">'MMMM d, yyyy'</span>);
    <span class="hljs-keyword">return</span> {
      slug,
      formattedDate,
      ...matterResult.data,
    };
  });
  <span class="hljs-keyword">return</span> allPostsData.sort(<span class="hljs-function">(<span class="hljs-params">a, b</span>) =&gt;</span> (<span class="hljs-keyword">new</span> <span class="hljs-built_in">Date</span>(a.date) &lt; <span class="hljs-keyword">new</span> <span class="hljs-built_in">Date</span>(b.date) ? <span class="hljs-number">1</span> : -<span class="hljs-number">1</span>));
}

<span class="hljs-comment">// Gets a single post by its slug (filename)</span>
<span class="hljs-keyword">export</span> <span class="hljs-function"><span class="hljs-keyword">function</span> <span class="hljs-title">getPostBySlug</span>(<span class="hljs-params">slug</span>) </span>{
  <span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> fullPath = path.join(postsDirectory, <span class="hljs-string">`<span class="hljs-subst">${slug}</span>.md`</span>);
  <span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> fileContents = fs.readFileSync(fullPath, <span class="hljs-string">'utf8'</span>);
  <span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> matterResult = matter(fileContents);
  <span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> formattedDate = format(<span class="hljs-keyword">new</span> <span class="hljs-built_in">Date</span>(matterResult.data.date), <span class="hljs-string">'MMMM d, yyyy'</span>);
  <span class="hljs-keyword">return</span> {
    slug,
    <span class="hljs-attr">content</span>: matterResult.content,
    formattedDate,
    ...matterResult.data,
  };
}

<span class="hljs-comment">// Gets all possible slugs for getStaticPaths</span>
<span class="hljs-keyword">export</span> <span class="hljs-function"><span class="hljs-keyword">function</span> <span class="hljs-title">getAllPostSlugs</span>(<span class="hljs-params"></span>) </span>{
  <span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> fileNames = fs.readdirSync(postsDirectory);
  <span class="hljs-keyword">return</span> fileNames.map(<span class="hljs-function">(<span class="hljs-params">fileName</span>) =&gt;</span> ({
    <span class="hljs-attr">params</span>: {
      <span class="hljs-attr">slug</span>: fileName.replace(<span class="hljs-regexp">/\.md$/</span>, <span class="hljs-string">''</span>),
    },
  }));
}

on a review of your project files, you need Tailwind CSS because it is the <b>only thing providing the styling</b> for your entire website. All the colors, layouts, text sizes, and design elements you asked for are built with it.</p><p>Here‚Äôs a breakdown of why it's essential for your project:</p><ul><li><p><b>It Creates the Visual Design</b>: Your homepage in <code>pages/index.js</code> uses Tailwind's utility classes to create the dark background, gradient colors, and large text that matches the design you wanted. Without classes like <code>bg-dark-navy</code>, <code>text-5xl</code>, and <code>font-extrabold</code>, the page would be plain white with black text.</p></li><li><p><b>It Provides the "Great CSS" for Your Blog</b>: You asked for a blog with "greate css" that doesn't feel static. This is achieved using the Tailwind Typography plugin. In your blog post template (<code>pages/blog/[slug].js</code>), the <code>className="prose prose-xl prose-invert..."</code> automatically applies beautiful, professional styling to the HTML that is generated from your markdown (<code>.md</code>) files. It styles your headings, paragraphs, links, and lists without you needing to write any separate CSS.js].</p></li><li><p><b>It Styles All Your Components</b>: Reusable components like your <code>BlogCard.js</code> use Tailwind classes like <code>shadow-md</code>, <code>rounded-lg</code>, and <code>overflow-hidden</code> to create the card layout for your featured posts.</p></li></ul><p>In short, if you were to remove Tailwind from this project, your website would lose its entire design and would be just plain, unformatted text. You need it because it's the tool used to fulfill your request for a modern, well-designed website.</p></div><!----></message-content><!----><!----><div _ngcontent-ng-c3182825971="" linear;"><p>Understood. You are using the correct professional workflow. Here is a clear explanation of how Git and Cloudflare Pages work together to deploy and host your website.</p><p>Your PC is your <b>development environment</b>, while Git (GitHub) and Cloudflare Pages are your <b>deployment and hosting pipeline</b>.</p><p></p><h3>The Workflow Explained</h3><p></p><p>Here is the step-by-step process that happens each time you want to update your website:</p><ol start="1"><li><p><b>You Make Changes on Your PC</b>: You edit your code‚Äîfor example, changing text on the homepage (<code>pages/index.js</code>) or adding a new component‚Äîon your local computer. This is the only part that happens on your PC.</p></li><li><p><b>You Push Your Changes to GitHub</b>: Using Git commands (<code>git add</code>, <code>git commit</code>, <code>git push</code>), you send your saved changes to your remote repository on GitHub (<code>Ravi877/rohithegde_newsite</code>). GitHub acts as the central storage for your code.</p></li><li><p><b>Cloudflare Pages Detects the Push</b>: Your Cloudflare Pages project is connected to your GitHub repository. As soon as you push new changes, Cloudflare is automatically notified.</p></li><li><p><b>Cloudflare Builds Your Website</b>: Cloudflare automatically starts a new "build" process. It downloads your code from GitHub and runs the build command you specified (<code>npx @cloudflare/next-on-pages@1</code>). This command uses the scripts in your <code>package.json</code> to turn your Next.js project into a set of optimized, static files that can be hosted.</p></li><li><p><b>Cloudflare Deploys and Hosts the Site</b>: Once the build is successful, Cloudflare takes the final output and deploys it across its global network. Your new website is now live for the world to see.</p></li></ol><p>In summary, you are correct. The website is not "on" your PC. Your PC is just the workshop where you build the parts. Git is the delivery truck, and Cloudflare Pages is the factory and the showroom where the final product is assembled and displayed.</p></div><!----></message-content><!----><!----><div <span class="hljs-keyword">import</span> fs <span class="hljs-keyword">from</span> <span class="hljs-string">'fs'</span>;
<span class="hljs-keyword">import</span> path <span class="hljs-keyword">from</span> <span class="hljs-string">'path'</span>;
<span class="hljs-keyword">import</span> matter <span class="hljs-keyword">from</span> <span class="hljs-string">'gray-matter'</span>;
<span class="hljs-keyword">import</span> { format } <span class="hljs-keyword">from</span> <span class="hljs-string">'date-fns'</span>;

<span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> postsDirectory = path.join(process.cwd(), <span class="hljs-string">'_posts'</span>);

<span class="hljs-keyword">export</span> <span class="hljs-function"><span class="hljs-keyword">function</span> <span class="hljs-title">getAllPosts</span>(<span class="hljs-params"></span>) </span>{
  <span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> fileNames = fs.readdirSync(postsDirectory);
  <span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> allPostsData = fileNames.map(<span class="hljs-function">(<span class="hljs-params">fileName</span>) =&gt;</span> {
    <span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> slug = fileName.replace(<span class="hljs-regexp">/\.md$/</span>, <span class="hljs-string">''</span>);
    <span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> fullPath = path.join(postsDirectory, fileName);
    <span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> fileContents = fs.readFileSync(fullPath, <span class="hljs-string">'utf8'</span>);
    <span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> matterResult = matter(fileContents);
    <span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> formattedDate = format(<span class="hljs-keyword">new</span> <span class="hljs-built_in">Date</span>(matterResult.data.date), <span class="hljs-string">'MMMM d, yyyy'</span>);
    <span class="hljs-keyword">return</span> { slug, formattedDate, ...matterResult.data };
  });
  <span class="hljs-keyword">return</span> allPostsData.sort(<span class="hljs-function">(<span class="hljs-params">a, b</span>) =&gt;</span> (<span class="hljs-keyword">new</span> <span class="hljs-built_in">Date</span>(a.date) &lt; <span class="hljs-keyword">new</span> <span class="hljs-built_in">Date</span>(b.date) ? <span class="hljs-number">1</span> : -<span class="hljs-number">1</span>));
}

<span class="hljs-keyword">export</span> <span class="hljs-function"><span class="hljs-keyword">function</span> <span class="hljs-title">getPostBySlug</span>(<span class="hljs-params">slug</span>) </span>{
  <span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> fullPath = path.join(postsDirectory, <span class="hljs-string">`<span class="hljs-subst">${slug}</span>.md`</span>);
  <span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> fileContents = fs.readFileSync(fullPath, <span class="hljs-string">'utf8'</span>);
  <span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> { data, content } = matter(fileContents);
  <span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> formattedDate = format(<span class="hljs-keyword">new</span> <span class="hljs-built_in">Date</span>(data.date), <span class="hljs-string">'MMMM d, yyyy'</span>);
  <span class="hljs-keyword">return</span> { slug, content, formattedDate, ...data };
}

<span class="hljs-keyword">export</span> <span class="hljs-function"><span class="hljs-keyword">function</span> <span class="hljs-title">getAllPostSlugs</span>(<span class="hljs-params"></span>) </span>{
  <span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> fileNames = fs.readdirSync(postsDirectory);
  <span class="hljs-keyword">return</span> fileNames.map(<span class="hljs-function">(<span class="hljs-params">fileName</span>) =&gt;</span> ({
    <span class="hljs-attr">params</span>: { <span class="hljs-attr">slug</span>: fileName.replace(<span class="hljs-regexp">/\.md$/</span>, <span class="hljs-string">''</span>) },
  }));
}

<span class="hljs-section">image: "/images/uploads/your-image.jpg"

<span class="hljs-section">## Welcome to My New Blog</span>

This is the main content of my blog post, written in <span class="hljs-strong">**Markdown**</span>. You can write paragraphs, create lists, and more.

<span class="hljs-section">### Key Features</span>
<span class="hljs-bullet">*</span> Static Site Generation (SSG) for amazing performance.
<span class="hljs-bullet">*</span> Content written in simple markdown files.
